payload.instructions:
# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!

<user_instructions>

# Agent Notes

- To run the OS in QEMU, use `make run-hdd`.
  - Prefer this over `make run`; the HDD target is the intended path for interactive runs.
- If you run `make run-hdd`, you won't be able to continue, because the process won't finish.  If you want to run it then kill it to get serial output, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`
- Standard build remains `make` (produces `os.img` and `hdd.img`).
- We have our own libc implementation (src/kernel/libc.c), and memory/heap management (malloc, calloc, realloc, free) in src/kernel/heap.c.  Use heap operations rather than trying to use fixed memory assigned in stage2.asm unless absolutely necessary.
- If you need to modify memory layout, make sure you keep STAGE2_BASE and STACK_TOP up-to-date to avoid smashing memory through overlaps in stage2.asm
- If you want to boot the kernel, the shell has a variety of commands (including shutdown) - which you can use to stop the kernel and return to your thinking

Thanks!



</user_instructions>

{"output":"# Userland ATK Applications

This prototype introduces a path for running ATK-based applications in userland while keeping the kernel’s video/ATK pipeline in control of global state (window chrome, focus, mouse routing) and hardware access.

## Architecture

* The kernel hosts **remote ATK windows** (`user_atk_window_t`). Each remote window is a normal ATK window that owns an `atk_image` child. The image points at a pixel buffer that the user process updates via a syscall.
* New syscalls expose the functionality:
  * `SYSCALL_UI_CREATE` – create a remote window (`user_atk_window_desc_t`).
  * `SYSCALL_UI_PRESENT` – copy a RGB565 buffer from userland into the window image and request a refresh.
  * `SYSCALL_UI_POLL_EVENT` – fetch mouse/key/close events; supports blocking.
  * `SYSCALL_UI_CLOSE` – tear a remote window down.
* `user_atk.c` in the kernel bridges ATK’s event handling:
  * `atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char` now consult `user_atk_host` helpers. When a remote window sits under the cursor, global focus is updated, window dragging/title-bar operations remain kernel-managed, and a per-window event queue receives content-space events.
  * Mouse capture is honoured so drags continue even if the cursor leaves the window.
  * Closing a window via the title bar emits a `USER_ATK_EVENT_CLOSE` for the owning process.
* When a process exits, all of its remote windows are closed automatically.

## Userland Toolkit

* We compile the ATK sources for userland with `ATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS` so shared code (window manager, widgets) is available without shell/task-manager dependencies. Rendering helpers (`video_*`) are provided by `user/video_surface.c`, which draws into a software buffer.
* `atk_user.c` wraps the UI syscalls. It owns the software surface, exposes `atk_user_window_open`, `atk_user_present`, `atk_user_wait_event`, and `atk_user_close`, and wires the surface into the ATK renderer.
* Because `video.h` was hard-coded, it now honours `VIDEO_WIDTH`/`VIDEO_HEIGHT` overrides. Userland builds set these constants (currently 640×360) so every ATK call uses the same logical surface size that the kernel remote window allocates.
* User apps render exactly like the kernel: they call `atk_render()` after ATK reports a redraw, then push the buffer via `atk_user_present`. Local widgets (text input, label, etc.) behave exactly as they do in kernel space because we instantiate a regular ATK window and slide it upward (negative Y) so the chrome is clipped before blitting into the remote frame.

## Event Model

Global vs. local responsibilities are split:

* **Global**: window chrome, z-order, focus changes and capture continue to live in the kernel ATK state. Mouse presses on titles still drag windows, the desktop still receives clicks, etc.
* **Local**: content-space events (mouse within the client area, key presses when the remote window has focus, close notifications) are delivered to the user process via the new syscalls. The user process feeds them into its ATK state (`atk_handle_mouse_event`/`atk_handle_key_char`) and decides when to redraw.

## Demo

`user/atk_demo.c` is a minimal userland GUI app:

1. Calls `atk_user_window_open` (title “ATK Demo”) to create a 640×360 remote window.
2. Initialises its own ATK state/theme, creates a single ATK window (Y shifted by `-ATK_WINDOW_TITLE_HEIGHT` so only the body is visible), adds a label + text input, and hooks the submit handler.
3. Runs an event loop that waits on `USER_ATK_EVENT_*`, passes mouse/key events into ATK, and redraws/presents whenever ATK sets the `redraw` flag.

The command `useratk` (wired into the shell) launches `/bin/atk_demo`, letting us exercise the full path end-to-end.

{"output":"CC       := x86_64-elf-gcc
LD       := x86_64-elf-ld
OBJCOPY  := x86_64-elf-objcopy
QEMU     := qemu-system-x86_64
HOST_CC  ?= cc

SRC_DIR     := src
ARCH_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/arch/x86
KERNEL_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/kernel
DRIVER_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/drivers
ATK_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/atk
NET_DIR     := $(SRC_DIR)/net
SBIN_DIR    := $(SRC_DIR)/sbin
CRYPTO_DIR  := $(SRC_DIR)/crypto
INCLUDE_DIR := include
USER_DIR    := user
OBJDIR      := build

CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
          -m64 -mno-red-zone -mgeneral-regs-only -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) -I$(ATK_DIR) \
          -fno-merge-constants -fno-asynchronous-unwind-tables -fno-unwind-tables \
          -fshort-wchar -mfpmath=387 -mno-sse

KERNEL_LD   := $(ARCH_DIR)/uefi.ld
LOADER_DIR  := src/loader

ARCH_KERNEL_SOURCES := $(filter-out $(ARCH_DIR)/uefi_boot.c,$(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.c))

C_SOURCES := \
	$(wildcard $(KERNEL_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(DRIVER_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/util/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(NET_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(wildcard $(CRYPTO_DIR)/*.c) \
	$(ARCH_KERNEL_SOURCES) \
	$(wildcard $(SBIN_DIR)/*.c)

C_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(C_SOURCES))

ASM_SOURCES := $(wildcard $(ARCH_DIR)/*.S)
ASM_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.S,$(OBJDIR)/%.o,$(ASM_SOURCES))

USER_OBJDIR := $(OBJDIR)/user
USER_CFLAGS := $(CFLAGS) -I$(USER_DIR) -I$(ATK_DIR) -DATK_NO_DESKTOP_APPS -DVIDEO_WIDTH=640 -DVIDEO_HEIGHT=360
USER_COMMON_SOURCES := \
	$(USER_DIR)/crt0.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/syscall.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/libc.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/atk_user.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/video_surface.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/serial_stub.c \
	$(USER_DIR)/atk_user_host_stub.c
USER_COMMON_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(USER_DIR)/%.c,$(USER_OBJDIR)/%.o,$(USER_COMMON_SOURCES))
USER_COMMON_OBJECTS += $(USER_OBJDIR)/kernel/font.o $(USER_OBJDIR)/kernel/ttf.o
USER_LD_SCRIPT := $(USER_DIR)/link.ld
USER_ATK_SOURCES := $(filter-out $(ATK_DIR)/atk_shell.c $(ATK_DIR)/atk_task_manager.c,$(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/*.c))
USER_ATK_SOURCES += $(wildcard $(ATK_DIR)/util/*.c)
USER_ATK_OBJECTS := $(patsubst $(SRC_DIR)/%.c,$(USER_OBJDIR)/%.o,$(USER_ATK_SOURCES))
USER_ELFS := $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.elf $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.elf $(USER_OBJDIR)/ttf_demo.elf
USER_BIN_DIR := build/bin
USER_BINS := $(USER_BIN_DIR)/userdemo2 $(USER_BIN_DIR)/atk_demo $(USER_BIN_DIR)/ttf_demo
HOST_TEST_DIR := $(OBJDIR)/host-tests
HOST_TEST_BIN := $(HOST_TEST_DIR)/ttf_host_test
HOST_TEST_CFLAGS := -std=c17 -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) -DTTF_HOST_BUILD

KERNEL_ELF := $(OBJDIR)/alix.elf
EFI_DIR    := build/EFI/BOOT
EFI_BIN    := $(EFI_DIR)/BOOTX64.EFI
DATA_IMG   := data.img
LOADER_SRC := $(LOADER_DIR)/uefi_loader.c
LOADER_CC  ?= x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc
LOADER_CFLAGS := -std=c11 -ffreestanding -fno-stack-protector -fno-builtin -fno-pic \
                 -mno-red-zone -Wall -Wextra -I$(INCLUDE_DIR) -fshort-wchar
LOADER_LDFLAGS := -nostdlib -Wl,--dll -Wl,--entry=efi_main -Wl,--subsystem,10 \
                  -Wl,--image-base,0x4000000 -Wl,--file-alignment,0x200 -Wl,--section-alignment,0x1000 \
                  -Wl,--major-subsystem-version,10 -Wl,--minor-subsystem-version,0

all: $(KERNEL_ELF) $(EFI_BIN) $(USER_ELFS) $(USER_BINS)

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(OBJDIR)/%.o: $(SRC_DIR)/%.S
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/%.o: $(USER_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/atk/%.o: $(ATK_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/atk/util/%.o: $(ATK_DIR)/util/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(USER_OBJDIR)/kernel/%.o: $(KERNEL_DIR)/%.c
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(CC) $(USER_CFLAGS) -c -o $@ $<

$(KERNEL_ELF): $(C_OBJECTS) $(ASM_OBJECTS) $(KERNEL_LD)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -z max-page-size=0x1000 -T $(KERNEL_LD) -o $@ $(C_OBJECTS) $(ASM_OBJECTS)

$(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.elf: $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.o $(USER_LD_SCRIPT)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(USER_LD_SCRIPT) -o $@ $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.o

$(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.elf: $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_ATK_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.o $(USER_LD_SCRIPT)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(USER_LD_SCRIPT) -o $@ $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_ATK_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.o

$(USER_OBJDIR)/ttf_demo.elf: $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_ATK_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/ttf_demo.o $(USER_LD_SCRIPT)
	@mkdir -p $(dir $@)
	$(LD) -nostdlib -T $(USER_LD_SCRIPT) -o $@ $(USER_COMMON_OBJECTS) $(USER_ATK_OBJECTS) $(USER_OBJDIR)/ttf_demo.o

$(USER_BIN_DIR)/userdemo2: $(USER_OBJDIR)/userdemo2.elf
	@mkdir -p $(USER_BIN_DIR)
	cp $< $@

$(USER_BIN_DIR)/atk_demo: $(USER_OBJDIR)/atk_demo.elf
	@mkdir -p $(USER_BIN_DIR)
	cp $< $@

$(USER_BIN_DIR)/ttf_demo: $(USER_OBJDIR)/ttf_demo.elf
	@mkdir -p $(USER_BIN_DIR)
	cp $< $@

$(HOST_TEST_BIN): tests/ttf_host_test.c src/kernel/ttf.c
	@mkdir -p $(HOST_TEST_DIR)
	$(HOST_CC) $(HOST_TEST_CFLAGS) tests/ttf_host_test.c src/kernel/ttf.c -o $@

LOADER_HEADERS := \
	$(INCLUDE_DIR)/uefi.h \
	$(INCLUDE_DIR)/bootinfo.h \
	$(INCLUDE_DIR)/arch/x86/bootlayout.h

$(EFI_BIN): $(LOADER_SRC) $(KERNEL_ELF) $(LOADER_HEADERS)
	@mkdir -p $(EFI_DIR)
	$(LOADER_CC) $(LOADER_CFLAGS) $(LOADER_LDFLAGS) -o $@ $<

$(DATA_IMG):
	truncate -s 4G $@

RAM ?= 4G
OVMF_CODE ?= vendor/OVMF_CODE.fd
OVMF_VARS ?= vendor/OVMF_VARS-1024x768.fd
QEMU_DEBUG_LOG   ?= qemu.log
QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS ?= -d cpu_reset,int,guest_errors,trace:ahci_*,trace:ide_*,trace:cmd_identify -D $(QEMU_DEBUG_LOG)
HOMEBREW_PREFIX  := $(shell brew --prefix)

# --- choose networking backend: user (slirp), vmnet-shared (NAT), vmnet-bridged (bridge en0)
NET_BACKEND ?= vmnet-shared

# Packet capture (works for all backends)
NETDUMP := -object filter-dump,id=n0dump,netdev=n0,queue=all,file=qemu-net.pcap

# Backend-specific NETDEV flags
NETDEV_user := -netdev user,id=n0,net=10.0.2.0/24,dhcpstart=10.0.2.15

# Defaults
QEMU_NET_PREFIX :=
NETDEV := $(NETDEV_user)

# vmnet-shared via socket_vmnet (rootless): wrap QEMU and use fd=3
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-shared)
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# vmnet-bridged via socket_vmnet (rootless): choose interface with VMNET_BRIDGE=en0/en1/...
ifeq ($(NET_BACKEND),vmnet-bridged)
  VMNET_BRIDGE ?= en0
  VMNET_SOCKET ?= $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/var/run/socket_vmnet.bridged.$(VMNET_BRIDGE)
  QEMU_NET_PREFIX := $(HOMEBREW_PREFIX)/opt/socket_vmnet/bin/socket_vmnet_client $(VMNET_SOCKET)
  NETDEV := -netdev socket,id=n0,fd=3
endif

# Device (keep RTL8139 + MAC)
NIC := -device rtl8139,netdev=n0,mac=52:54:00:12:34:56

run: $(EFI_BIN) $(DATA_IMG) $(USER_ELFS) $(USER_BINS)
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \
	$(QEMU) -nodefaults -m $(RAM) -machine q35,accel=kvm:tcg \
		-drive if=pflash,unit=0,format=raw,readonly=on,file=$(OVMF_CODE) \
		-drive if=pflash,unit=1,format=raw,file=$(OVMF_VARS) \
		-drive if=none,id=fsdisk,file=fat:rw:build,format=raw \
		-device ahci,id=ahci0 \
		-device ide-hd,drive=fsdisk,bus=ahci0.0 \
		-drive if=none,id=data,file=$(DATA_IMG),format=raw,media=disk \
		-device ide-hd,drive=data,bus=ahci0.1 \
		-no-reboot -monitor vc:1280x1024 -serial stdio -vga std \
		$(QEMU_DEBUG_FLAGS) $(NETDEV) $(NETDUMP) $(NIC)

run-hdd: $(EFI_BIN) $(DATA_IMG) $(USER_ELFS) $(USER_BINS)
	$(QEMU_NET_PREFIX) \

payload.text:
**Designing and implementing Wolf3D game components**

I'm laying out a plan to add the Wolf3D binary to the build system, handling Makefile targets, linking decisions, shell commands, and user binary integration. Then, I'm sketching the core C code: defining map data, player state, fast trigonometric functions, gradient background rendering, raycasting with DDA, color shading, input handling for WASD movement and rotation, and safe drawing routines—all to build a minimalist Wolfenstein-like 3D game using the ATK user window framework.

**Finalizing movement logic and build integration**

I'm refining player movement functions, defining map checks, key handling with smooth movement and rotation, and setting up player initialization. Then I’ll proceed with implementing build system updates, shell command hookups, and organizing source files to tie the Wolf3D app into the existing infrastructure.

I’ll likely have to edit the main source file carefully or script selective replacements to make this consistent without breaking unrelated code.

payload.text:
**Restructuring floating-point functions to avoid SSE return**

I’m figuring out how to fix compile errors caused by functions returning double with SSE disabled; since x86_64 SysV ABI requires SSE registers for double returns, I plan to replace these problematic functions with macros or void functions using pointer parameters to avoid returning floating types. For example, I'll convert `wolf_absd` to a macro and merge `wolf_fast_sin` and `wolf_fast_cos` into one void function returning results via pointers, while updating `wolf_wrap_angle` to a void function taking pointers as well. This approach should sidestep ABI issues by eliminating floating-point return values while preserving functionality.

**Explaining SSE enablement challenges**

I’m putting together a detailed explanation of why SSE isn’t just enabled here: it requires kernel support to manage FPU state, extended registers, and context switching, which the current kernel avoids by using compile flags like `-mno-sse` (`Makefile:14`). I’ll reference `src/kernel/process.c` as the place handling context switches but only for general registers. This should clarify why enabling SSE means updating kernel structures, managing CR0/CR4 bits, and more—so it’s not trivial to just switch on.

payload.text:
**Explaining SSE disabling rationale and constraints**

I'm laying out why SSE is disabled in both kernel and user code due to Makefile flags like `-mgeneral-regs-only -mno-sse`, pointing out that kernel avoids SSE to prevent interrupt corruption since interrupts only save general registers, not SSE. Using SSE would require rewriting interrupt stubs to save SSE state and updating context switching, so enabling SSE isn't just flipping a compile flag but involves substantial kernel changes. I’ll also clarify userland SSE could be enabled if kernel keeps SSE disabled but that requires separate compilation flags and careful handling to avoid conflicts.

payload.message:
Because our kernel can’t “just” flip a compiler flag without deeper architectural work:

- `Makefile:15-22` forces `-mgeneral-regs-only -mno-sse` for every translation unit, including userland, so the compiler never emits SSE instructions. That isn’t arbitrary—the kernel’s interrupt/exception entry paths (`src/arch/x86/process_preempt.S`, `src/kernel/process.c:420-520`) only save/restore the general-purpose register set. We rely on SSE registers never being touched while we’re in kernel mode, otherwise an interrupt could preempt code that has live XMM temps, corrupt the pending user-space SSE state, and resume with garbage.
- We do allocate and switch an FPU/SSE state block per thread (`fpu_state_t` with `fxsave/fxrstor` in `src/kernel/process.c:52-520`), but this only runs when a thread yields in the scheduler. It does not cover arbitrary kernel code paths, so letting the kernel use SSE would require every ISR, syscall entry, and preemption handler to spill/rest XMM/YMM state (or to implement lazy-FPU with CR0.TS management and #NM handling). None of that plumbing exists yet.
- Enabling SSE globally would also mean auditing all stack-alignment rules, updating the boot code to configure CR0/CR4/XSAVE bits consistently, and handling faults like #XM/#UD that currently can’t happen. Until that infrastructure is in place, the safest option is to keep the compiler from emitting SSE entirely.
- We could, in theory, split the flags so that only userland apps drop `-mgeneral-regs-only -mno-sse`, but even then we’d need to be 100% sure the kernel stays SSE-free (and probably add CI checks) before touching the global flags.

So “just enable SSE” isn’t a one-line change—it would ripple through the ABI, interrupt frame layout, scheduler, and boot-time CPU setup.

**Evaluating SSE enablement complexity**

I’m analyzing kernel build flags, CPU control registers, and current SSE use to see what enabling full SSE support entails. It looks like the CPU and paging setup already allows SSE instructions, but the kernel build disables SSE to avoid context-switch overhead. To enable full SSE, I'd need to overhaul save/restore of SSE state not just at task switches but also on interrupts, which is complex and costly. I'm considering whether partial SSE for userland only or full kernel-wide SSE with expensive context handling fits the user’s request better.

payload.name: apply_patch
payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Add File: docs/sse.md
+# SSE Enablement
+
+This document captures the current SSE policy for Alix along with the audit
+trails that make userland SIMD code safe.
+
+## Build and Toolchain
+
+- Kernel objects continue to be compiled with `-mgeneral-regs-only -mno-sse
+  -mfpmath=387`. This keeps kernel code strictly integer/x87 so no SSE
+  registers are ever touched while we are running in privileged mode.
+- Userland objects now use `-msse2 -mfpmath=sse -mstackrealign` (see
+  `Makefile`). Every user process can freely execute SSE/SSE2 instructions.
+
+## CPU/FPU configuration
+
+- `src/arch/x86/kernel_entry.c` sets CR0 and CR4 bits (`OSFXSR`, `OSXMMEXCPT`,
+  clears `EM`, sets `MP`, `PG`) during early boot, so the CPU accepts SSE/SSE2
+  instructions from both privilege levels.
+- `fpu_prepare_initial_state()` performs `fninit`/`fxsave64` once and each
+  thread inherits a copy of this clean image before running.
+
+## Context switching
+
+- Scheduler transitions (`process.c`) always invoke `fxsave64`/`fxrstor64`
+  in `fpu_save_state`/`fpu_restore_state`. User threads therefore retain their
+  XMM state across yields, preemption and blocking syscalls.
+- Because kernel code never executes SSE instructions (see build flags), the
+  only owner of the SIMD register file is the currently scheduled thread.
+  Interrupt/exception entry does not need additional save/restore work — the
+  registers are untouched until the thread is either resumed or a context
+  switch occurs.
+
+## Interrupts and exceptions
+
+- All interrupt handlers live in C (`src/arch/x86/interrupts.c`) and inherit the
+  kernel compilation flags, so they stay SSE-free.
+- The syscall entry path (`src/arch/x86/syscall_entry.S`) switches stacks and
+  registers without touching XMM/YMM state; the callee runs with the same
+  guarantees as other kernel code.
+
+## Stack alignment
+
+- User-mode stacks are allocated and aligned in `process_prepare_stack_with_args`
+  and `process_jump_to_user`. We align the initial stack pointer down to 16 and
+  respect the SysV AMD64 convention so SSE instructions that require aligned
+  operands (e.g. `movaps`) are safe.
+- Kernel thread stacks are also 16-byte aligned inside `thread_create`, which is
+  important for any future kernel code that might opt-in to SSE via explicit
+  save/restore wrappers.
+
+## Future work
+
+- If the kernel ever needs SSE for fast memcpy/crypto/etc., we will need
+  wrappers similar to Linux’s `kernel_fpu_begin/end` that save/restore per
+  thread state on demand, plus ISR glue that records whether a context switch
+  occurred before attempting to restore.
+- Additional exception handlers for SIMD faults (#19) can be added to deliver
+  cleaner diagnostics to userland if we start unmasking MXCSR bits.
*** End Patch

{"output":"# alix

## Building (UEFI only)

The BIOS pipeline is gone. We now build two artifacts:

1. `build/alix.elf` – the actual kernel image (ELF64, linked at 0x0010_0000).
2. `build/EFI/BOOT/BOOTX64.EFI` – a tiny UEFI loader that reads `\alix.elf`, loads its PT_LOAD segments, collects firmware data (GOP, ACPI, memory map), exits boot services, and jumps into the kernel.

Run `make` and both binaries will be produced in the `build/` tree that we export to QEMU as a FAT drive. You still need the usual cross toolchain (`x86_64-elf-gcc`, `binutils`, etc.).

## Running in QEMU with OVMF

1. Download OVMF from the Tianocore project and place the firmware blobs at:
   - `vendor/OVMF_CODE.fd`
   - `vendor/OVMF_VARS-1024x768.fd`
2. Run `make run-hdd` (preferred) or `make run`. Both targets launch QEMU with:
   - `-nodefaults -machine q35,accel=kvm:tcg`
   - A virtio VGA device plus a FAT-backed drive that points at the `build/` directory (`-drive format=raw,file=fat:rw:build`)
   - The RTL8139 NIC wired through the existing socket_vmnet plumbing if enabled
   - Serial routed to stdio and a 1024x768 monitor window
   - Debug and trace channels enabled via `-d cpu_reset,int,guest_errors,trace:ahci_*,trace:ide_*,trace:cmd_identify`

The running kernel provides a shell (`shutdown` exits cleanly). If you need to terminate QEMU manually while preserving serial logs, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`.
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.2}}

{"output":"     1	# alix
     2	
     3	## Building (UEFI only)
     4	
     5	The BIOS pipeline is gone. We now build two artifacts:
     6	
     7	1. `build/alix.elf` – the actual kernel image (ELF64, linked at 0x0010_0000).
     8	2. `build/EFI/BOOT/BOOTX64.EFI` – a tiny UEFI loader that reads `\alix.elf`, loads its PT_LOAD segments, collects firmware data (GOP, ACPI, memory map), exits boot services, and jumps into the kernel.
     9	
    10	Run `make` and both binaries will be produced in the `build/` tree that we export to QEMU as a FAT drive. You still need the usual cross toolchain (`x86_64-elf-gcc`, `binutils`, etc.).
    11	
    12	## Running in QEMU with OVMF
    13	
    14	1. Download OVMF from the Tianocore project and place the firmware blobs at:
    15	   - `vendor/OVMF_CODE.fd`
    16	   - `vendor/OVMF_VARS-1024x768.fd`
    17	2. Run `make run-hdd` (preferred) or `make run`. Both targets launch QEMU with:
    18	   - `-nodefaults -machine q35,accel=kvm:tcg`
    19	   - A virtio VGA device plus a FAT-backed drive that points at the `build/` directory (`-drive format=raw,file=fat:rw:build`)
    20	   - The RTL8139 NIC wired through the existing socket_vmnet plumbing if enabled
    21	   - Serial routed to stdio and a 1024x768 monitor window
    22	   - Debug and trace channels enabled via `-d cpu_reset,int,guest_errors,trace:ahci_*,trace:ide_*,trace:cmd_identify`
    23	
    24	The running kernel provides a shell (`shutdown` exits cleanly). If you need to terminate QEMU manually while preserving serial logs, run `killall qemu-system-x86_64`.
    25	
    26	## SIMD / SSE support
    27	
    28	User processes are now built with SSE2 enabled (and `mfpmath=sse`) so they can use double-precision math and vector code freely. The kernel remains SSE-free for now; refer to `docs/sse.md` for the full design notes and auditing details.
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.2}}

{"output":"     1	# SSE Enablement
     2	
     3	This document captures the current SSE policy for Alix along with the audit
     4	trails that make userland SIMD code safe.
     5	
     6	## Build and Toolchain
     7	
     8	- Kernel objects continue to be compiled with `-mgeneral-regs-only -mno-sse
     9	  -mfpmath=387`. This keeps kernel code strictly integer/x87 so no SSE
    10	  registers are ever touched while we are running in privileged mode.
    11	- Userland objects now use `-msse2 -mfpmath=sse -mstackrealign` (see
    12	  `Makefile`). Every user process can freely execute SSE/SSE2 instructions.
    13	
    14	## CPU/FPU configuration
    15	
    16	- `src/arch/x86/kernel_entry.c` sets CR0 and CR4 bits (`OSFXSR`, `OSXMMEXCPT`,
    17	  clears `EM`, sets `MP`, `PG`) during early boot, so the CPU accepts SSE/SSE2
    18	  instructions from both privilege levels.
    19	- `fpu_prepare_initial_state()` performs `fninit`/`fxsave64` once and each
    20	  thread inherits a copy of this clean image before running.
    21	
    22	## Context switching
    23	
    24	- Scheduler transitions (`process.c`) always invoke `fxsave64`/`fxrstor64`
    25	  in `fpu_save_state`/`fpu_restore_state`. User threads therefore retain their
    26	  XMM state across yields, preemption and blocking syscalls.
    27	- Because kernel code never executes SSE instructions (see build flags), the
    28	  only owner of the SIMD register file is the currently scheduled thread.
    29	  Interrupt/exception entry does not need additional save/restore work — the
    30	  registers are untouched until the thread is either resumed or a context
    31	  switch occurs.
    32	
    33	## Interrupts and exceptions
    34	
    35	- All interrupt handlers live in C (`src/arch/x86/interrupts.c`) and inherit the
    36	  kernel compilation flags, so they stay SSE-free.
    37	- The syscall entry path (`src/arch/x86/syscall_entry.S`) switches stacks and
    38	  registers without touching XMM/YMM state; the callee runs with the same
    39	  guarantees as other kernel code.
    40	
    41	## Stack alignment
    42	
    43	- User-mode stacks are allocated and aligned in `process_prepare_stack_with_args`
    44	  and `process_jump_to_user`. We align the initial stack pointer down to 16 and
    45	  respect the SysV AMD64 convention so SSE instructions that require aligned
    46	  operands (e.g. `movaps`) are safe.
    47	- Kernel thread stacks are also 16-byte aligned inside `thread_create`, which is
    48	  important for any future kernel code that might opt-in to SSE via explicit
    49	  save/restore wrappers.
    50	
    51	## Future work
    52	
    53	- If the kernel ever needs SSE for fast memcpy/crypto/etc., we will need
    54	  wrappers similar to Linux’s `kernel_fpu_begin/end` that save/restore per
    55	  thread state on demand, plus ISR glue that records whether a context switch
    56	  occurred before attempting to restore.
    57	- Additional exception handlers for SIMD faults (#19) can be added to deliver
    58	  cleaner diagnostics to userland if we start unmasking MXCSR bits.
","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":0.2}}

payload.text:
**Summarizing key project updates**

I’m gathering everything about enabling SSE in userland, including Makefile changes, new documentation, the Wolf3D user app with its shell command hook, and how we kept the kernel SSE-free. I’ll also cover tests, instructions for running Wolf3D, and suggest next steps like hooking textures or extending SSE into the kernel, organized in a clear bullet format.

payload.message:
**Changes**
- Split the toolchain so only userland emits SSE instructions: the kernel still builds with the old integer-only flags while user processes now use `-msse2/-mfpmath=sse/-mstackrealign`, all wired through the new `BASE_CFLAGS`/`KERNEL_CFLAGS`/`USER_CFLAGS` plumbing at `Makefile:19-107`. This keeps privileged code SSE-free but unlocks SIMD (and doubles) for every user binary.
- Captured the SSE audit in `docs/sse.md:1-58` and linked it from `README.md:26-28`, spelling out the CR0/CR4 setup, `fxsave/fxrstor` usage, interrupt behavior, and stack-alignment guarantees so future contributors understand why the new configuration is safe.
- Added a full Wolfenstein-style raycaster in `user/wolf3d.c:17-457`: it builds the map/physics layer, performs per-column DDA ray casts, shades walls/sky/floor, and handles WASD/QE input plus ESC/close events via the existing ATK userland surface.
- Hooked the binary into the shell: `/bin/wolf3d` is launched by the new command handler in `src/sbin/cmd_wolf3d.c:1-49`, the dispatcher entry was added in `include/shell_commands.h:30-34`, and the command list + help text were updated in `src/sbin/shell.c:262-305`.

**Tests**
- `make -j8`

**Next Steps**
1. Run `wolf3d` inside QEMU via the new `wolf3d` shell command to confirm input latency and rendering speed meet expectations.
2. If kernel-side SIMD ever becomes desirable, follow the path outlined in `docs/sse.md` (wrapping kernel SSE usage with explicit save/restore) to keep user contexts intact.

content.text:
**Changes**
- Split the toolchain so only userland emits SSE instructions: the kernel still builds with the old integer-only flags while user processes now use `-msse2/-mfpmath=sse/-mstackrealign`, all wired through the new `BASE_CFLAGS`/`KERNEL_CFLAGS`/`USER_CFLAGS` plumbing at `Makefile:19-107`. This keeps privileged code SSE-free but unlocks SIMD (and doubles) for every user binary.
- Captured the SSE audit in `docs/sse.md:1-58` and linked it from `README.md:26-28`, spelling out the CR0/CR4 setup, `fxsave/fxrstor` usage, interrupt behavior, and stack-alignment guarantees so future contributors understand why the new configuration is safe.
- Added a full Wolfenstein-style raycaster in `user/wolf3d.c:17-457`: it builds the map/physics layer, performs per-column DDA ray casts, shades walls/sky/floor, and handles WASD/QE input plus ESC/close events via the existing ATK userland surface.
- Hooked the binary into the shell: `/bin/wolf3d` is launched by the new command handler in `src/sbin/cmd_wolf3d.c:1-49`, the dispatcher entry was added in `include/shell_commands.h:30-34`, and the command list + help text were updated in `src/sbin/shell.c:262-305`.

**Tests**
- `make -j8`

**Next Steps**
1. Run `wolf3d` inside QEMU via the new `wolf3d` shell command to confirm input latency and rendering speed meet expectations.
2. If kernel-side SIMD ever becomes desirable, follow the path outlined in `docs/sse.md` (wrapping kernel SSE usage with explicit save/restore) to keep user contexts intact.

## My request for Codex:
We earlier disabled keyboard repeat entirely - re-enable it, but with an initial repeat rate backoff - so first keypress, a 500ms gap before repeat, then 200ms per key entry, until key release.

Make a proc filesystem, and add an entry for keyboard control to control both these values.

We earlier disabled keyboard repeat entirely - re-enable it, but with an initial repeat rate backoff - so first keypress, a 500ms gap before repeat, then 200ms per key entry, until key release.

Make a proc filesystem, and add an entry for keyboard control to control both these values.

**Planning keyboard repeat and timer integration**

I'm sorting out how to organize keyboard repeat support so it initializes after the timer setup to ensure timing ticks are valid. I plan to split keyboard init into parts—basic scancode setup first, then enabling repeat after timer_init—while adding new state and helper functions to handle key repeat logic, including managing scancodes, extended keys, and arrow sequences. I’m also designing a procfs interface for configuring repeat delays and rates, along with converting ms to tick counts based on timer frequency once it's set. This setup will keep repeat behavior consistent and adjustable through a procfs file.

 ## SIMD / SSE support
 
 User processes are now built with SSE2 enabled (and `mfpmath=sse`) so they can use double-precision math and vector code freely. The kernel remains SSE-free for now; refer to `docs/sse.md` for the full design notes and auditing details.
+
+## Keyboard repeat controls
+
+Runtime keyboard repeat behaviour lives under `/proc/keyboard_repeat`. Reading the file reports the current delays (milliseconds). Writing two integers (e.g. `echo "initial=600 repeat=150" >/proc/keyboard_repeat`) updates the initial pause before repeating begins and the steady-state cadence.
*** End Patch

payload.message:
- **Keyboard repeat + controls** – `src/drivers/keyboard.c:20-367` now keeps full repeat state, polls `timer_ticks()` for the 500 ms/200 ms cadence, replays scancodes via `keyboard_emit_char`, bumps the pending buffer to 64 entries, and exposes the knobs via `/proc/keyboard_repeat`. Reads return `initial_delay_ms`/`repeat_interval_ms` while writes accept either `"<initial> <repeat>"` or `initial=… repeat=…`; the parser and proc callbacks live at `src/drivers/keyboard.c:405-452`. The README documents the usage (`README.md:26-30`).  
  _Tip_: run `cat /proc/keyboard_repeat` to inspect the current settings and `echo "initial=600 repeat=150" >/proc/keyboard_repeat` to adjust them live.

- **Procfs + VFS plumbing** – VFS nodes can now supply custom read/write callbacks (`include/vfs.h:13-34`, `src/kernel/vfs.c:640-741`), which lets us publish synthetic data without copying strings around. A lightweight procfs layer (`include/procfs.h:1-10`, `src/kernel/procfs.c:1-40`) creates `/proc` at boot, and `kernel_main` wires it in before devices and after VFS (`src/kernel/kernel.c:208-225`). Keyboard init is deferred until after `timer_init` so repeat math always knows the PIT frequency.

- **Build/test** – `make -j8`

Let me know if you’d like a helper shell function or userspace tool for tweaking the repeat timings interactively.

content.text:
- **Keyboard repeat + controls** – `src/drivers/keyboard.c:20-367` now keeps full repeat state, polls `timer_ticks()` for the 500 ms/200 ms cadence, replays scancodes via `keyboard_emit_char`, bumps the pending buffer to 64 entries, and exposes the knobs via `/proc/keyboard_repeat`. Reads return `initial_delay_ms`/`repeat_interval_ms` while writes accept either `"<initial> <repeat>"` or `initial=… repeat=…`; the parser and proc callbacks live at `src/drivers/keyboard.c:405-452`. The README documents the usage (`README.md:26-30`).  
  _Tip_: run `cat /proc/keyboard_repeat` to inspect the current settings and `echo "initial=600 repeat=150" >/proc/keyboard_repeat` to adjust them live.

- **Procfs + VFS plumbing** – VFS nodes can now supply custom read/write callbacks (`include/vfs.h:13-34`, `src/kernel/vfs.c:640-741`), which lets us publish synthetic data without copying strings around. A lightweight procfs layer (`include/procfs.h:1-10`, `src/kernel/procfs.c:1-40`) creates `/proc` at boot, and `kernel_main` wires it in before devices and after VFS (`src/kernel/kernel.c:208-225`). Keyboard init is deferred until after `timer_init` so repeat math always knows the PIT frequency.

- **Build/test** – `make -j8`

Let me know if you’d like a helper shell function or userspace tool for tweaking the repeat timings interactively.

payload.input:
*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: README.md
@@
-## Keyboard repeat controls
-
-Runtime keyboard repeat behaviour lives under `/proc/keyboard_repeat`. Reading the file reports the current delays (milliseconds). Writing two integers (e.g. `echo "initial=600 repeat=150" >/proc/keyboard_repeat`) updates the initial pause before repeating begins and the steady-state cadence.
+## Keyboard repeat controls
+
+Runtime keyboard repeat behaviour lives under `/proc/keyboard/repeat/{initial,repeat}`. Each file contains a single integer in milliseconds. For example, `cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/initial` shows the current initial delay, and `echo 150 >/proc/keyboard/repeat/repeat` shortens the steady-state cadence. Updates take effect immediately.
*** End Patch

+
+User binaries can be executed directly via Linux-style path invocation (for example `./bin/userdemo2 arg1`). The legacy `runelf` command still exists, but `./` is now the preferred shorthand.
*** End Patch

payload.text:
**Summarizing key code changes and next steps**

I'll create a final message outlining the main modifications with file references and instructions, covering the `/proc/keyboard/repeat` restructuring, `wolf3d` autopilot run, and shell execution updates. I’ll include notes on tests run, README updates, and suggested commands for verification to guide the user clearly.

payload.message:
- `/proc/keyboard/repeat` is now a directory tree instead of a single mixed-value file. `src/kernel/procfs.c:8-173` grew helpers to create nested procfs paths, and `src/drivers/keyboard.c:20-456` now exports `/proc/keyboard/repeat/initial` and `/proc/keyboard/repeat/repeat`, each reading/writing a single integer while updating the live repeat timers. The README’s proc section (`README.md:26-33`) was updated accordingly.
- `user/wolf3d.c:17-470` now saves the current repeat timing (via the new proc files), forces the delay to 0 ms / 100 ms while the app runs, and restores the original values on exit or early failure. This keeps movement snappy in-game without permanently changing system behavior.
- Executable paths behave like a Linux shell: `src/sbin/shell.c:255-452` detects commands containing `/` and routes them through the new shared launcher instead of demanding the `runelf` verb. That launcher lives in `src/sbin/cmd_runelf.c:1-196`, so the original `runelf` command internally reuses the same logic. The helper is declared in `include/shell.h:37-43`, and the greeting strings advertise the new `./path` shorthand. (The shell readiness line still lists existing commands; `runelf` remains for backwards compatibility.)
- Plumbing tweaks to support the above: procfs helpers in `include/procfs.h:5-18`, `include/libc.h:24-30` now declares `open`, and README plus doc updates record the new behavior.

**Tests**
- `make -j8`

**Next steps**
1. Boot the OS (`make run-hdd`) and verify `cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/initial` / `repeat` show separate values, can be edited individually, and `wolf3d` temporarily overrides them.
2. In the shell, try `./bin/atk_demo` (or any other binary) to confirm the new path execution flow, and optionally compare with the legacy `runelf`.

payload.text:
**Summarizing fix and new features**

I'll explain how routing path executions through the kernel command runner solves window and input issues by unifying wait hooks and focus handling, plus mention the new helper and changes like the `/proc/keyboard/repeat` files and wolf3d update.

payload.message:
- `/proc/keyboard/repeat` is now a directory with independent files: `.../initial` and `.../repeat`. `src/kernel/procfs.c` gained helpers to build nested proc paths from strings, and `src/drivers/keyboard.c` exports each timing value via tiny read/write stubs that accept a single integer (newline optional). The README was updated with the new usage.  
- `user/wolf3d.c` now snapshots those two files on startup, forces 0 ms initial delay / 100 ms repeat for fast movement, and restores the saved values on exit (or when the window fails to open).  
- `./path` launching now goes through the exact same worker path as `runelf`: `shell_execute_line` allocates a temporary `"path [args]"` string, hands it to the existing `shell_cmd_runelf` via a background command runner, and frees it afterward (`src/sbin/shell.c`, `src/sbin/cmd_runelf.c`). The command runner struct now tracks owned argument buffers, so memory is freed automatically. Because `./` invocations once again use the same kernel thread, wait hooks and process scheduling behave exactly like `runelf`, eliminating the delayed-window/keyboard issues. The shell banner also mentions the shorthand explicitly.  
- `shell_execute_binary` was promoted to a shared helper (declared in `include/shell.h`) so `runelf` and the new implicit path handler share the same logic. `include/libc.h` now declares `open`, which wolf3d uses to tweak `/proc`.

**Tests**
- `make -j8`

You should now see the user window appear immediately and receive keyboard focus whether you launch it via `runelf` or `./bin/foo`. Use `cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/initial` and `/repeat` to confirm wolf3d restores the original timings when it quits.

**Reworking fallback command execution**

I'm figuring out how to unify fallback path executions by routing them through the existing async command infrastructure, especially reusing the runelf command handler. To do this safely, I plan to extend the command task structure to own dynamically allocated args strings, building combined path-and-args strings on fallback, and ensure proper cleanup after command completion to avoid leaks. This approach should preserve consistent asynchronous behavior without duplicating execution logic.

payload.message:
- Path-style executions now run through the same asynchronous command pipeline as `runelf`. `shell_execute_line` detects a `/` command, builds a `"path [args]"` string, and dispatches it via a synthetic `shell_cmd_runelf` task (`src/sbin/shell.c:389-545`). The task struct now owns any heap-allocated argument string, freeing it after the handler finishes, so the helper stays leak-free.
- The `runelf` handler itself simply invokes the shared `shell_execute_binary`, but when triggered through the shorthand it now benefits from the same background kernel thread, wait hooks, and foreground process handling as every other command. This restores the immediate window creation + keyboard focus you get with `runelf`.

**Next step:** Reboot/run the shell, launch an app via both `runelf /bin/atk_demo` and `./bin/atk_demo`, and confirm the window shows instantly and accepts input in both cases.

Finally, I plan to update the README to document these changes and clean up old macros.

*** Begin Patch
*** Update File: README.md
@@
-## Keyboard repeat controls
-
-Runtime keyboard repeat behaviour lives under `/proc/keyboard/repeat/{initial,repeat}`. Each file contains a single integer in milliseconds. For example, `cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/initial` shows the current initial delay, and `echo 150 >/proc/keyboard/repeat/repeat` shortens the steady-state cadence. Updates take effect immediately.
+## Keyboard repeat controls
+
+Runtime keyboard repeat behaviour lives under `/proc/keyboard/repeat/{initial,repeat,multi_mode}`. Each file contains a single integer (`initial`/`repeat` in milliseconds, `multi_mode` as 0/1). For example:
+
+```
+cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/initial        # view delay
+echo 150 >/proc/keyboard/repeat/repeat   # shorten repeat interval
+echo 1 >/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode # enable multi-key repeats for games
+```
+
+Changes apply immediately system-wide, so games can toggle `multi_mode` when they need true simultaneous key input.
*** End Patch

payload.text: **Updating README and code for multi mode**

payload.message:
- **Keyboard driver** – Repeat handling is now per-key, so simultaneous key presses can continue emitting characters in parallel. `src/drivers/keyboard.c` tracks up to 8 active scancodes, schedules their own delay/interval timers, and (optionally) keeps multiple repeats running concurrently. A new procfs node `/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` (0/1) toggles the behavior, while the existing `/proc/keyboard/repeat/{initial,repeat}` files still expose the timing knobs. Games can enable multi mode when they want overlapping movement + turning and disable it afterward.
- **Wolf3D** – The userland demo uses the new interface (`user/wolf3d.c`). On launch it snapshots the current repeat delays and `multi_mode`, drops the initial delay to 0 ms, the interval to 100 ms, and turns multi mode on. On exit (or startup failure) it restores all three values so the rest of the system behaves as before.
- **Docs** – The README’s keyboard section notes the extra proc file and shows sample commands (`cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode`, `echo 1 > …`) so users know how to toggle the chording-friendly mode.

**Tested** with `make -j8`.  
To verify at runtime:  
1. `echo 1 >/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` then hold `w` and tap `a`/`d` in a game; `w` continues firing.  
2. Launch `wolf3d`; confirm it forces fast repeats + multi-mode during play, then `cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/*` afterwards to see the original values restored.

The game should auto-enable multi_mode on boot, then disable it on exit.

That behavior is already in place: `wolf3d` snapshots `/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` before it starts, forces it to `1` while the game runs, and writes the saved value back when the app exits (or if it fails to open the window). So multi-mode is auto-enabled for gameplay and restored afterwards without any manual steps.

Multi-key repeat is already implemented and hooked up:

- `src/drivers/keyboard.c:1-250` defines a pool of repeat entries (`KEYBOARD_MAX_REPEAT_KEYS`) plus the `/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` control. When `multi_mode` is 0 the driver behaves exactly like before (only one repeating scancode). When it’s 1 we keep a repeat slot per pressed key so holding `W` while tapping `A`/`D` keeps the forward key active.
- `keyboard_start_repeat()` and `keyboard_repeat_due()` (around lines 140–230) now iterate the entry array instead of a single global, so every key that’s held continues to emit repeats independently.
- The procfs plumbing (`keyboard_init()` at line ~320) creates `/proc/keyboard/repeat/{initial,repeat,multi_mode}` so you can inspect or change all three values live.
- Wolf3D already toggles the new switch: `user/wolf3d.c` reads `multi_mode`, sets it to 1 while the app runs, then restores the saved value on exit.

If you’re not seeing the behavior, double-check `/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` in your running build—`cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` should print `1` whenever the mode is enabled (Wolf3D does this automatically).

content.text:
Multi-key repeat is already implemented and hooked up:

- `src/drivers/keyboard.c:1-250` defines a pool of repeat entries (`KEYBOARD_MAX_REPEAT_KEYS`) plus the `/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` control. When `multi_mode` is 0 the driver behaves exactly like before (only one repeating scancode). When it’s 1 we keep a repeat slot per pressed key so holding `W` while tapping `A`/`D` keeps the forward key active.
- `keyboard_start_repeat()` and `keyboard_repeat_due()` (around lines 140–230) now iterate the entry array instead of a single global, so every key that’s held continues to emit repeats independently.
- The procfs plumbing (`keyboard_init()` at line ~320) creates `/proc/keyboard/repeat/{initial,repeat,multi_mode}` so you can inspect or change all three values live.
- Wolf3D already toggles the new switch: `user/wolf3d.c` reads `multi_mode`, sets it to 1 while the app runs, then restores the saved value on exit.

If you’re not seeing the behavior, double-check `/proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` in your running build—`cat /proc/keyboard/repeat/multi_mode` should print `1` whenever the mode is enabled (Wolf3D does this automatically).
